metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of Daman Superstation, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Daman superstation eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2021. The site (100.37223° E, 38.85551° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556.06 m. The EC was installed at a height of 4.5 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3&Li7500A) was 0.17 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record; and (4) data were rejected at night when the friction velocity (u*) was less than 0.1 m/s. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. Due to the malfunction of power, data during May 15 to June 12 were missing.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used in oasis-desert ecosystems involves acquiring half-hourly turbulent flux data using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, complemented by hydrometeorological data from automatic weather stations, which include radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, among other variables.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered in measuring evapotranspiration in arid regions, and how has it been addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in measuring evapotranspiration in arid regions is the uncertainty in surface-air temperature difference, which affects the performance of models like the TSEB model. This has been addressed by using ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures, improving the accuracy of evaporation and transpiration estimates.

Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset comprises observations from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, covering energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters, collected from 2012 to 2021 across multiple stations.

Definition.Question: How is the concept of 'two-source energy balance (TSEB) model' applied in estimating evapotranspiration for vegetated land surfaces?
Definition.Answer: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model is used to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) by treating the soil and vegetation as separate sources of energy exchange. It accounts for the partition of energy between these sources and requires inputs such as soil and canopy component temperatures, which can be obtained using high-resolution thermal cameras, to improve the accuracy of ET estimates, especially in heterogeneous landscapes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data processing steps between datasets collected for the Heihe River Basin surface process observation network and those collected for oasis-desert energy and carbon exchange?
Comparison.Answer: For the Heihe River Basin, data processing involves using Eddypro software to handle 30-minute flux values, including steps like coordinate rotation and density corrections. Oasis-desert energy and carbon exchange datasets involve data processing and quality control, such as data collection, processing, archiving, and sharing, with half-hourly turbulent flux data acquired by different instruments. Both datasets emphasize quality control but use different software and procedural steps due to the varied environmental conditions and data focus.

Comparison.Question: In terms of challenges faced during data collection, how does the issue of data gaps due to power supply problems compare to the challenges of uncertainties in component temperature estimation in arid regions?
Comparison.Answer: Data gaps due to power supply issues present a direct challenge in terms of missing temporal data, which affects the continuity and completeness of the dataset. On the other hand, uncertainties in component temperature estimation, particularly in arid regions, arise from image classification errors and atmospheric conditions, leading to potential inaccuracies in measured fluxes. While power supply issues affect data availability, temperature estimation uncertainties impact data accuracy and reliability.

Interpretation.Question: What data collection techniques can be inferred from the combination of eddy covariance systems and thermal infrared cameras for estimating evapotranspiration in complex agricultural environments?
Interpretation.Answer: The field observations involved using an eddy covariance system to measure turbulent fluxes and a thermal infrared camera to capture soil and canopy component temperatures. These methods allow for the estimation of evapotranspiration by partitioning it into evaporation and transpiration, using canopy and soil component temperatures as inputs to a two-source energy balance model.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges can be inferred from the need for quality control procedures in collecting energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include ensuring accurate long-term data collection in harsh environments, managing data quality from multiple instruments like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, and dealing with data gaps caused by environmental factors or equipment issues. Rigorous data processing and quality control procedures are necessary to maintain the integrity of datasets that inform understanding of oasis-desert interactions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of stable isotope techniques with eddy covariance measurements enhance the understanding of evapotranspiration processes in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration allows for better validation of evapotranspiration components, providing insights into the ratios of evaporation and transpiration. By using stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, researchers can validate and refine models of water and energy exchange, enhancing the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimates in environments with heterogeneous surfaces.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately estimating surface fluxes in irrigated agricultural areas using data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes is challenging due to the incomplete energy balance closure in EC flux measurements and uncertainties in surface-air temperature differences. These uncertainties arise from errors in determining component temperatures and the strong advective environment in irrigated areas, which affect the performance of models like the TSEB.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the need for rigorous data processing methods for eddy covariance data in the context of oasis-desert systems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for rigorous data processing arises from the complex interactions and exchanges of energy, water vapor, and carbon in oasis-desert ecosystems. Challenges such as ecological degradation, drying of water bodies, and dust storms require precise and high-quality data to understand and manage these systems sustainably.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the limitations of current temperature separation approaches in arid regions when measuring evapotranspiration components?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Current temperature separation approaches are limited by image classification errors that vary with vegetation abundance, leading to overestimation of canopy temperatures. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance contributes to uncertainties in estimated temperatures, affecting the accuracy of E and T measurements.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind establishing a comprehensive observation network for surface processes in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to understand the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to achieve goals such as carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, and to support the ecological security and sustainable development of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is the collection of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes crucial for understanding oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The collection of long-term data is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions, protecting ecological stability, and supporting the socioeconomic development of oases, which is significant for maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems to achieve sustainable development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the steps involved in processing eddy covariance data to ensure quality control and reliability in flux measurement datasets?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The processing of eddy covariance data involves several steps to ensure quality control and reliability, including: despiking to remove outliers, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, and WPL correction for density fluctuations. Additionally, the data undergo quality evaluation based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity tests. Data with errors, those collected during rainfall, and those with more than 10% missing data in the original 10Hz samples are removed. The processed data are averaged over 30-minute intervals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are thermal infrared images utilized to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures for evapotranspiration modeling in heterogeneous landscapes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Thermal infrared images are utilized by first classifying visible and NIR images into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures are then extracted from these thermal images. These temperatures are converted into radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the emissivities of the soil and canopy. The simulated radiometric temperatures are then validated against surface radiometric temperatures measured by a four-component radiometer.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What observational techniques are employed to collect long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems are collected using a combination of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for turbulent flux measurements. Hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles, are obtained from automatic weather stations. Additionally, groundwater table data, as well as vegetation and soil parameters, are supplemented in the datasets.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods using eddy covariance systems face challenges in arid and semiarid regions when estimating energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes?
Expectation.Answer: In arid and semiarid regions, the eddy covariance system might face challenges due to incomplete energy balance closure, strong advection, and errors in determining surface temperatures, which can affect the accuracy of flux measurements.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to utilize high-resolution thermal imaging in the collection of soil and canopy component temperatures for estimating evapotranspiration?
Expectation.Answer: High-resolution thermal imaging is important because it provides accurate soil and canopy component temperatures, which are crucial for estimating evapotranspiration accurately using models like the TSEB model, especially in heterogeneous landscapes.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated benefits of maintaining long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial for understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems, supporting sustainable development, and helping achieve carbon peaking and neutrality goals by providing quantitative insights into energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using eddy covariance systems in capturing accurate flux measurements in arid and semi-arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of eddy covariance systems is a common method for capturing flux measurements in arid and semi-arid regions. However, challenges such as incomplete energy balance closure and environmental conditions like strong advection can impact the accuracy of the measurements. The effectiveness can be enhanced by incorporating additional techniques such as isotope analysis, as demonstrated in the field exploration.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced in separating soil and canopy temperatures using thermal infrared cameras for evapotranspiration studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The separation of soil and canopy temperatures using thermal infrared cameras is a complex task, particularly in arid regions where image classification errors can occur. These errors can lead to overestimation of canopy temperatures. To overcome these challenges, accurate classification methods and corrections for atmospheric conditions are essential.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the potential for extending observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems to improve understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges?
Judgmental.Answer: Extending observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems is crucial for improving understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Despite the challenges of environmental degradation, long-term data collection from multiple stations and the inclusion of auxiliary parameters can provide comprehensive insights into ecosystem interactions and support sustainable development goals.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data quality is maintained when processing data from eddy covariance systems in these complex environmental settings.
Assertion.Answer: Data quality is maintained by applying a rigorous data processing protocol. This includes removing outliers, correcting time delays, rotating coordinates, and applying frequency response corrections. Quality evaluations focus on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity, and data from periods with instrument errors or significant data gaps are excluded.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data processing and quality control procedures necessary for managing long-term ecological observations in arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data processing and quality control for managing long-term ecological observations in arid regions involve multiple steps: data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. This methodical approach ensures the reliability and usability of data, considering the complexities of measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, which are critical for maintaining ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss the potential for integrating thermal infrared imaging in evaluating evapotranspiration models in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.
Request/Directive.Answer: Thermal infrared imaging can be integrated into the evaluation of evapotranspiration models like the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. In the context of strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas, high-resolution thermal cameras can provide soil and canopy component temperatures, which enhance the model's ability to accurately estimate evaporation, transpiration, and overall evapotranspiration. This integration addresses challenges related to composite temperature separation and increases the accuracy of surface flux estimations.
